Abstract

Proposal Number: EPS-1003970

Proposal Title: Advancing and Supporting Science, Engineering, and Technology II

Institution: Arkansas Science and Technology Authority


This RII-4 proposal seeks to enhance Arkansas?s scientific research capability by focusing on three areas in renewable energy: plant biosynthesis, alternate energy, and nanotechnology. The research in the plant biosynthesis area will focus on efficient plant-based bioproduction of high-value proteins, unique bioactive chemicals, and renewable biomaterials. The development of cost-effective, high efficiency solar cells is the objective the alternate energy area. The research in the nanotechnology area is directed at the fabrication of new materials to be integrated into photovoltaic devices. The Arkansas researchers proposed to package these devices, as well.

The research will be conducted in three existing Arkansas centers: the Center for Plant-Powered Production (P3 Center), the Center for Generating Renewable Energy with Efficient Nanoplasmonic Solar Cells (GREEN Center), and the Vertically Integrated Center for Transformative Energy Research (VICTER).

Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in the compelling nature of the research, both in terms of the potential for advancing science and as a national need. Solar cells and photovoltaic materials offer an attractive alternative to fossil fuels. Green plants, capture and convert solar energy to sugars, oils and a vast array of chemicals contributing to both energy and chemical feed-stocks enabling. Significant challenges remain for cost-effective renewable energy sources that are capable of seamless integration into the national power grid. The P3 Center will explore the fundamental mechanisms involved in the synthesis, regulation, trafficking and storage of phytochemicals and the basis of bioactivity of these phytochemicals on target organisms The GREEN Center is focused on the development of cost-effective, high-efficiency solar cells that utilize surface plasmon photonics and unique nanomaterials. The discovery, fabrication and utilization of new nanoscale materials and films for alternate energy needs will be addressed in the VICTER Center.The proposed research will enable multidisciplinary teams to focus on key issues in solar cell efficiency and plasmonics, in PV materials, packaging, and integration into the power grid, and in enhancing the ability of plants to function as factories for biofuels, bioactive phytochemicals and biomaterials.


Broader Impacts
The proposed project has significant depth in its outreach activities. The project expands on the previous RII proposal by including two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) institutions and two 4-year colleges. Numerous secondary school research activities and professional development for teachers and two-year college faculty are proposed in order to support the STEM pipeline. There are tightly woven educational and workforce development activities directly tied to the specific research themes. Heavy emphasis is placed on summer research experiences for undergraduates. The project provides internships for Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) students to expand matriculation into graduate programs. There is a program of mentoring for graduate students, postdoctoral and young faculty. Numerous activities support public engagement such as Research Day at the Capital, REU research competition at annual meetings, and competitions such as the solar boat race. External Engagement and Workforce Development are addressed in part by ensuring that the three centers have incorporated interactions with industry and/or expectation of technology spin-off companies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) Research Infrastructure Improvement (RII) Project known as ASSET II (Advancing and Supporting Science, Engineering and Technology) was successful at increasing the physical and juman research infrastructure in the state of Arkansas.  The project attained the following:

  • involved 690 participants, including 199 graduate and 269 undergraduate students;
  • expanded research collaborations (400 individuals in 215 institutions- 50% out of state);
  • purchased $6.6 million of research equipment;
  • submitted $259 million in proposals;
  • received $76 million in extramural funding;
  • developed/expanded over 10 private companies;
  • disseminated 1,075 presentations and 670 publications;
  • submitted 14 patents; and
  • engaged 835 K-12 teachers and 14,166 K-12 students in educational outreach.

Key research outcomes in the engineering and biotechnology areas include:  1) development  of efficient light emitters  made from Germanium-Tin (Ge-Sn) alloys;  2) new microinverters (converting DC generated current to AC current) that contain several major improvements including a novel micro-Hall sensor that relies on a magnetically sensitive semiconductor and an important advance in silicon carbide (SiC) integrated circuits which will have applications in many other areas where rugged electronics are needed;  and 3) within our plant biosciences efforts, identification of a specific plant gene that controls biological and pharmaceutical activity of stilbenoids, a plant-produced chemical with anti-aging and anticancer effects. 

Adding Tin to Germanium is known to increase the efficiency of light-emitting diodes. The problem has been that Tin is not very soluble in Germanium and the added Tin can create new problems as the concentration is increased. Therefore, the successful synthesis of a Germanium/Tin alloy with low levels of Tin and efficient light emission marks an important milestone in this area. 

Our researchers have dramatically improved accuracy and efficiency of solar inverters by replacing older more traditional voltage gauges with highly sensitive micro-Hall devices.  The sensor has effective and stable operation at high temperatures and over a wide temperature range, measure AC and DC signals, and is extremely small.  The team set the world record for unique integrated circuitry that will operate in harsh conditions.  The research team has now designed and built over 40 circuits in SiC that will operate at over 500 C° making these devices suitable for energy grid applications, tolerant of space exploration conditions, and excellent components for transportation applications. 

Our biotechnology teams have used chemical fingerprints of cellular processes and messenger RNA data to identify and control a key gene in plant systems critical in making a uniquely important group of plant products known as stilbenoids. This gene controls the addition of protein-protein binding structures to stilbenoids, which increases the activation of this compound when it enters the body.  Furthermore, this discovery provides a new tool for engineering of plant or microbial systems to produce activated stilbenoids with commercial importance, such as crops with increased disease resistance, therapeutic agents and nutraceuticals that promote health benefits.
